column3: for the third night in a row she slipped out at half past ten and made her way to the edge of the estate
column4: where Aleandro would wait for her near an abandoned wine cellar
column5: which had become their meeting place.

column1: 2230|ten-thirty|They have their first fight at ten-thirty that night. It’s over who’s going to sleep in the bed and who’s going to sleep on the couch. Billy insists that she take the bed
column2:
says he’ll be fine on the couch.
“That’s sexist.”
“Sleeping on the couch is sexist? Are you kidding me?”
“Being a manly man is sexist. You’re too long for it. Your feet will hang out on the floor.”

column1: 2230|ten thirty|“What are you getting?” He addressed this to the air in front of him
column2:
without turning toward her.
“I’m sorry?”
“I’ve been sent for ice
column4:
nothing. I’m off home.”
“At ten thirty on New Year’s Eve? That is either the saddest or the wisest thing I’ve ever heard.”

column2: Kendra found herself on the couch again
column3: this time with Christy. She felt uncomfortable sitting next to her
column4: especially after the barrage of hate her coworkers had thrown at the blonde
column5: but Christy seemed unusually approachable right then
column6: all smiles and laughs and easy-flowing gestures.

column1: 2230|ten thirty|She looked at the clock; it was ten thirty. If she could get there quickly on the subway
column2: then she could be at his house in less than an hour
column3: maybe a bit longer if the late trains did not come so often.

column1: 2230|ten-thirty|The time was ten-thirty but it could have been three in the morning
column3: West Berlin goes to bed with the dark

column1: 2230|half past ten o’clock|From the untoward lateness of the hour at which the dose was administered
column2: it was half past ten o’clock before any effects began to show themselves in this case.
